Award.AwardTitle: Microbial Systems in the Biosphere: Unraveling the Lifestyles of Dominant Freshwater Fe-oxidizing Bacteria
Award.AbstractNarration:
IOS 0951077 - Microbial Systems in the Biosphere: Unraveling the Lifestyles of
Dominant Freshwater Fe-oxidizing Bacteria

PI: David Emerson, Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences

Bacteria are remarkable for their metabolic diversity and ability to utilize seemingly unpalatable food sources. The Fe-oxidizing bacteria (FeOB) are a prime example, since they gain energy for growth by oxidizing ferrous iron to ferric iron (rust). These bacteria are prolific and easily recognized by abundant rust-colored precipitates that form whereever ferrous iron is present in natural waters, or in domestic and industrial water distribution systems. The work funded by this proposal will investigate the systematics, ecology, and physiology of a particular group of freshwater FeOB. The systematics are important because we do not know the true identity of some of the most important FeOB; without knowing who they are it is impossible to reliably identify them. The ecology is important because we know different types of FeOB have very specific habitat requirements. Figuring out those requirements may provide an easy way to determine aspects of water quality that are specific for a given group of FeOB. This could be a good diagnostic tool for assessing water quality. The physiology studies are important because we actually know very little about how, or even why, bacteria oxidize iron. By answering these questions we can learn about an important fundamental biological process. This may allow better control over it, or allow us to harness it for beneficial purposes. To investigate these questions we will employ a host of modern microbiological and chemical techniques that allow us to study cells in their natural environments at the microscale, as well as reproduce those controlled conditions in the laboratory. Ultimately this work will improve our understanding of a long recognized, but poorly understood group of microbes, of significant environmental importance, both as nuisance organisms that cause biofouling and corrosion, and as beneficial organisms that can remove metals and other pollutants from water.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to learn more about the ecology, physiology, and systematics of a unique group of bacteria that live through utilization of iron as their primary food source. While this may seem like an arcane lifestyle, these bacteria are actually common, in part because iron is an abundant element, and readily available for microbial metabolism in soils and oxygen poor waters. In such waters, these bacteria can grow to abundance and form rusty microbial mats that can be centimeters thick. From a practical point of view, these bacteria cost the water industry billions of dollars a year through clogging and corrosion of wells and pipelines as well as discoloration and contamination of domestic water supplies. On the beneficial side, however, is the fact that the biogenic iron oxides produced by these bacteria are reactive with and can bind a host of inorganic and organic pollutants, thus if their growth is controlled they could be put to use in, for example, water purification.     

This project has contributed to our understanding of the significant role these bacteria play in the biological iron cycle. This is important because there is still a lack of consensus on the importance of biological iron oxidation as a primary biogeochemical process. Many scientists remain, at best agnostic, as to whether much of the naturally occurring Fe-oxidation is a purely chemically driven process. This work has further characterized naturally occurring freshwater iron-oxidizing mats and confirmed the abundant presence of specific groups of bacteria highly adapted for growth on iron. It has enhanced our understanding of the complex ecological relationships between different populations of iron-oxidizing bacteria. The work lends support to the idea that iron-oxidizing communities are not random associations of different bacteria, but form a functionally coherent community that is optimized for gaining energy and resources from iron oxidation.  What is also interesting is that this community may extend beyond just members that utilize iron for energy, but include other microbes that are specific to these communities and carry out other functions that we do not fully understand yet. 

One of the most prolific members of iron-oxidizing communities is Leptothrix ochracea, an organism that produces a hollow, tubular sheath composed mostly of iron-oxides. We showed that a single 100 micrometer filament of L. ochracea could produce up to one meter of sheath per day, explaining why these organisms, or their byproducts, compose the essential fabric of these Fe-oxidizing microbial mats. Work done during this project used state of the art techniques for studying bacteria in situ, to confirm the systematics of L. ochracea for the first time in the 150 years since it was first described. Detailed analysis of the microbial mats where it lives have revealed unusual and complex behavioral responses where it forms what appears to be a concerted front that literally constructs the microbial mat as the cells grow. This is illustrated in the attached photomicrograph. Attempts at cultivation revealed that L. ochracea requires iron for growth, and apparently some components of its natural waters; nonetheless, it was still not possible to isolate the organism. Single cell analysis revealed L. ochracea does not readily take-up organic carbon, but may both fix carbon dioxide as well as take up some organic carbon in mixtrophic growth. This may explain its preference for waters with higher concentrations of dissolved organic matter than other obligate iron-oxidizing bacteria.
